Key Arguments: The ACMA should not have the power to make or enforce laws.
The ACMA has a poor track record in promoting decency in media, particularly regarding content inappropriate for children.
The ACMA is not equipped to be the arbiter of truth and should not defer to independent experts not accountable to the government or democracy.
The legislation undermines free speech, freedom of religion, and democracy by potentially enforcing narratives or viewpoints.
Citizens should be trusted to determine truth and engage in public debate without censorship or manipulation by the ACMA.
Main Themes: Parental rights and protection of children
Concerns about censorship and narrative control
Notable Quotes: The ACMA should never be given power to make or enforce laws.
The ACMA is not in the position to be the arbiter of truth.
It is unreasonable for the ACMA to enforce a narrative, philosophy, or a view on religion, science, education, politics, medicine etc.
The ACMA must treat Australian citizens with respect and dignity and trust them with the responsibility of determining what is true and what is false.
